reasoning: The critique targets the independence assumption in the toy multiplicative model in §2.4. That model is supportive of (and rhetorically important for) the ‘eutopia is fragile’ claim, but it is not the essay’s only (or even main) support for ‘no easy eutopia’—the position also relies heavily on the long list of plausible single-point moral failures and on the later §3 argument about bounded/unbounded moral views. So centrality is moderate-low. The point has some force: strong positive correlations among “civilizational competence” factors would make the toy model’s distribution less skewed and could make mostly-great futures more common than the independent-uniform product suggests. However, the critique overstates this as “breaking” the inference: the essay presents the product model explicitly as a toy/illustrative model and only claims ‘relatively independent factors’; moreover, many cited dimensions could be weakly correlated, nonlinearly related, or even negatively correlated across moral perspectives, so adding correlation doesn’t straightforwardly rescue easy-eutopia. Thus strength is limited. The critique is mostly correct in the narrow sense (independence is a substantive assumption and covariance matters), but it makes a stronger conclusion than warranted, so correctness isn’t perfect. It’s clear, focused, and contains essentially no dead weight.
title: Correlated civilizational competencies undermine the independent factors model
